rows.text: Wide band gap p-type CuBO2 nanostructures by hydrothermal route
and fabrication high quality p-CuBO2/n-ZnO nano-heterojunction
S. Santraa, N.S. Dasa, S. Maitia, K.K. Chattopadhyaya,b,⇑
a
Thin Film &Nanoscience Laboratory, Department ofPhysics,Jadavpur University, Kolkata 700 032, India
b
School ofMaterials Science &Nanotechnology,Jadavpur University, Kolkata 700 032, India
article info
Article history:
Received 20 March 2014
In final form 25 April 2014
Available online 2 May 2014
abstract
CuBO2 nanocubes were synthesized for the first time through hydrothermal route. Beside compositional,
morphological, structural and optical studies of the materials, I–V characteristics of the fabricated p-
CuBO2/n-ZnO was measured using conducting atomic force microscopy which showed excellent diode
behavior with an ideality factor 1.03 and very small leakage current 0.04 nA.
¿2; 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
1. Introduction
During the last two decades, extensive research in materials sci-
ence and nanotechnology was dedicated to find novel nanomateri-
als with improved functionalities. Significant improvement has
been achieved in the controlled synthesis of diverse nanomaterials
for wide variety of applications. Fabrication ofactive devices using
transparent conducting oxides (TCO) is a very challenging task
because of the scarcity of stable p-TCOs and limited success has
been achieved so far [1–5]. On the other hand prospects in applica-
tion of such devices are in many attractive fields; for examples,
fabrication of functional windows through which visible light
could pass but by using the UV portion of solar spectrum some
power can be generated. In principle, all the electronics circuits
can be made transparent and a new field has emerged called
transparent electronics [6].
Among the TCOs, ZnO, having high exciton binding energy and
wide optical band gap, has emerged as the most promising candi-
date for UV light emitting diode (UV-LED) [7,8]. ZnO homojunction
has been used for this purpose in most of the cases [9–11]. How-
ever, reproducibility of conductivity and stable p-type nature of
p-ZnO is always challenging for industry and search for proper sta-
ble p-type counterpart is therefore required [12]. So heterojunction
formed with classic p-type TCOs like NiO, CuO and n-type ZnO are
extensively studied [13,14]. However, there are certain criteria for
obtaining efficient junction based electrical transport properties.
Such as, similar energy band structure, compatible conductivity,
less lattice mismatch, etc. Classic p-type TCOs often fail to fulfill
these requirement resulting in less efficient junction properties.
Led by this practical need, Cu delafossites were developed as
potential p-type candidates for device based applications [15,16].
These are usually ternary oxides having unique crystal structure
where metal planes and O atoms connected by dumbbell Cu atoms
[1] resulting in chemically modulated valance band where the
electron pairs of O atoms become delocalized and offers enhanced
conductivity. CuAlO2 emerged as the most popular p-type TCO in
this field. Several attempts have been made to enhance the con-
ductivity of CuAlO2 and other Cu delafossites by different groups
including ours by doping and incorporating defects [17–19]. In
spite ofall those efforts, electrical conductivity ofp-type TCOs even
for the Cu delafossites is still inferior to n-type TCOs and further
research regarding this is urgently required. It has been proved
that delafossites of Cu(M)O2 form are expected to exhibit higher
band gap as the ionic radius of M decreases. This indicates that
CuBO2 should have the largest optical band gap among the Cu del-
afossites [20,21 ]. Undoped CuBO2 also possess very high room tem-
perature electrical conductivity [21] claiming itself a potential
candidate forjunction fabrication with n-type TCOs. On the other
hand in comparison to single micro object based devices, devices
fabricated by assembly of several nano objects should offer better
functionalities hence much broadened applicability [22]. Till now,
synthesis of nanostructured CuBO2 is rarely reported [23,24]. Nei-
ther the possibility ofuse ofthis novel delafossite for nanojunction
fabrication has been ever explored. In this work we have synthe-
sized CuBO2 nanostructures through hydrothermal route for the
first time and investigated the effect of synthesis time on the mor-
phology of the same. The formation of p–n heterojunction with
ZnO one dimensional nanorods was also established. This easy
and efficient synthesis process is expected to be effective for future
large scale production of multifunctional [25–27] p-type CuBO2
nanostructures with enhanced optical and electrical properties
forjunction based device fabrication.

2. Experimental details
All the reagents used to prepare nanocrystalline CuBO2 cubes
were analytically pure and used without further purification. Com-
mercially available (CH3COO)2Cu¿2;H2O (99.99%) and Na2B4O7¿2;10H2
O (99.99%) were dissolved separately in deionized water and
stirred continuously at room temperature for 30 min to prepare
0.17 M solution of (CH3COO)2Cu¿2;H2O and 0.04 M solution of Na2B4
O7¿2;10H2O. The prepared solutions were then mixed up and stirred
for 3 min to form homogeneous transparent mixture. NaOH solu-
tion (0.2 M) was then added to the mixture and stirred for 2 min.
The above mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless
steel autoclave (100 mL capacity) that was filled with the mixture
to 80% of the total volume. The autoclave was kept at 200 ¿3;C tem-
perature for different durations (1, 2 and 3 h) under autogenerated
pressure. After naturally cooling down, the products were collected
via filtration and washed for several times with deionized water.
Afterwards, the products were dried in vacuum oven at 50 ¿3;C for
12 h. The obtained powders were then collected and labeled as
sample A (synthesis duration 1 h), sample B (synthesis duration
2 h) and sample C (synthesis duration 3 h).
The morphological, structural, compositional and optical char-
acterizations of the as-prepared samples were carried out by
FESEM, HRTEM, XRD, EDX and UV–Vis spectroscopy respectively.
The details of characterization are provided in ESI; electrical
properties and junction based performance of CuBO2/ZnO system
was studied using conducting atomic force microscopy.
The EDX spectra (Figure S1, ESI) of the samples showed energy
peaks corresponding to B (Ka), O (Ka) and Cu (Ka) confirming
nearly stoichiometric formation of the CuBO2 delafossite. Detail
analysis of EDX results can be found in ESI.
3. Results and discussion
The FESEM images of the CuBO2 samples are shown in Figure 1.
The micrographs show that in case of sample A, CuBO2 nanoparti-
cles are attached together to form larger particles but no specific
shape was formed within 1 h duration. Well distributed CuBO2
nanocubes are formed in case of sample B. The nanocubes were
also found to be formed by smaller particulated units. However,
for sample C, the nanocubes were deformed and smaller building
units of CuBO2 were larger in size than in case of sample B.
Exact dimensions of the nanocubes and exact shape of the
building units for sample B were studied by HRTEM. All the cubes
were almost same in shape and size (Figure S2a) with an average
dimension of ¿3;300 nm. Figure 1d depicts the TEM micrograph of
a single nanocube showing that the elongated building units of
CuBO2 nanocubes are actually nanorods of diameter ¿3;12 nm. The
lattice image of those nanorods is shown in inset of Figure 1d.
The d spacing was measured to be 2.33 Å which correspond to
the (012) plane of CuBO2 lattice. The SAED pattern of sample B
was also recorded (Figure S2b) and the diffraction spots were
indexed according to the planes of the hexagonal CuBO2 lattice,
among them the most intense diffraction spot was observed for
(012) plane.
Figure 2 shows the XRD patterns of samples A, B, C. The distinct
and intense diffraction peaks indicated good crystallinity and
proper phase formation ofCuBO2 delafossite (JCPDS 28–1256) with
some preferred orientation along (012) planes. The texture coeffi-
cients (TC(hkl)) for all the samples for all planes were calculated
using the following expression [28–30]
TCðhklÞ¼ IðhklÞ=I0ðhklÞ
1nPn
i¼1 IðhklÞ =I0ðhklÞ ð 1 Þ
and the results are presented in ESI Table S1. It was observed
that the values of texture coefficients were highest for sample B
for each plane of CuBO2 lattice.
The probable growth mechanism of CuBO2 nanocubes were
analyzed in two steps, firstly the growth of smallest building
blocks of the nanocubes, i.e. CuBO2 nanorods and secondly, the
preferred orientation was investigated.
During the hydrothermal process, firstly the early grown CuBO2
nanoparticles worked as the nuclei for further growth. After one
hour growth, a number of almost spherical CuBO2 nanoparticles
attached with each other to form larger agglomeration. That is
why the nature ofthe CuBO2 agglomeration was not perfectly cubi-
cal in shape and edges were not sharp as the growth was not com-
pleted within one hour (sample A). This assumption is supported
by Figure 1a and the smallest building units are almost spherical
in nature (inset of Figure 1a). When the growth duration was
increased (sample B), the CuBO2 nanoparticles attached with each
other to form small CuBO2 nanorods. Thus we found little elon-
gated building units for sample B (inset ofFigure 1d). Those nano-
rods worked as the main building unit of CuBO2 nanocubes. This
phenomenon is illustrated in Figure 3. The edges of the nanocubes
became much sharper due to proper growth of the nanocubes.
However, for sample C, the reaction time increased and the nano-
rods (which were composed of small nanoparticles) agglomerated
Figure 1. (a), (b) and (c) FESEM images of sample A, B and C respectively, (d)
HRTEM images of sample B, insets show the higher magnification images.
Figure 2. XRD patterns of CuBO2 samples prepared with various time durations.
98 S. Santra et al./Chemical Physics Letters 604 (2014) 97–100
with each other leaving behind no specific structure ofthe smallest
building units as we found in inset of Figure 1c.
It was found from HRTEM results that lattice spacing observed
for CuBO2 nanorods of sample B was ¿3;2.33 Å. This d value corre-
spond to (012) plane ofhexagonal CuBO2 lattice. The reason behind
this preferred orientation was also analyzed. It is well known that
JCPDS data is mostly used to confirm and compare the experimen-
tal results for d spacing. However, JCPDS data are usually taken
using single phase powder samples i.e. for randomly oriented sam-
ples. The contribution from lattice impurities, preferred orientation
are not included in case ofJCPDS data. The calculation of texture
coefficient for any randomly distributed crystal system becomes
much simpler and the value of TChkl becomes 1 for such system.
It may be therefore concluded that as the value of TChkl for any
(hkl) plane shall approach 1 if the plane is randomly oriented.
Reversely, the planes having preferred orientation should have
TChkl value much deviated from 1. From Table S1 (please see Sup-
porting information), we can see that the value ofTChkl has highest
difference from 1 in case of (012) planes for sample B and such
planes are having preferred orientation. That is in full agreement
with our HRTEM results where preferred orientation of the
nanorods along (012) plane was observed.
The transmission spectra of all the samples A, B and C were
recorded which confirmed good transparency of the samples and
the band gaps (¿3;3.6 eV) of the same were also determined. The
results are discussed in detail in ESI.
Several procedures for synthesizing ZnO nanostructures
through wet chemical route are reported till now. Dissolving metal
oxides in acidic medium and subsequently reducing the same with
base treatment has been reported earlier by Tiwari et al. [31] We
have earlier reported room temperature synthesis of ZnO nano-
structures through KMnO4 activation of substrates using KOH
and zinc nitrate as precursors [32]. In this study ZnO nanostruc-
tures (Figure 4a) were grown on commercially available ITO sub-
strates using the same chemical method as employed in our
earlier study [32]. CuBO2 nanocubes (sample B) were spin coated
over the ZnO nanostructures and pure ITO substrates and the I–V
characteristics of both the systems were measured using AFM.
For this, appropriate bias voltage was applied across the ITO and
Pt coated AFM tip as shown (Figure 4b). The I–V characteristic of
pure CuBO2 nanocubes is presented in Figure 4c. It can be seen that
single CuBO2 nanocube shows almost symmetric current for
the entire range of forward and reverse bias voltage. Whereas,
Figure 4d clearly depicts the diode nature of p-CuBO2/n-ZnO
heterojunction.
The experimental forward current–voltage characteristic was
fitted using the following relationship:
I ¼ I0ðexp
qV
nkT¿4;1Þ ð2Þ
Where, I is the current through the diode, Vis the voltage across
the diode, I0 is the dark saturation current, n is the ideality factor
and T is the temperature in kelvin, q is the electronic charge and
k is Boltzmann constant.
Different values the above parameters found in this work are
presented in Table S2 where other reported values are also com-
pared. It can be seen from the table that ZnO/CuBO2 heterojunction
exhibits better or equivalent diode performance which definitely
indicate that CuBO2 is really a promising p-type candidate forjunc-
tion based device fabrication.
4. Summary
In summary, CuBO2 nanostructures were prepared first time via
easy hydrothermal method with various synthesis durations.
Proper phase formation was confirmed by X-ray diffraction studies.
The morphological properties were studied by FESEM and HRTEM.
The synthesis duration was demonstrated to play the controlling
role for the formation of CuBO2 nanocubes.
I–V characteristics of the fabricated p-CuBO2/n-ZnO was mea-
sured using conducting atomic force microscopy which showed
excellent diode behavior with an ideality factor 1.03 and very small
Figure 3. Schematic representation of growth of CuBO2 samples.
Figure 4. (a) Cross sectional view of ZnO nanospikes, (b) schematic of AFM I–V
measurement, (c) I–V characteristics of pure CuBO2 nanocube, (d) I–V character-
istics of p-CuBO2/n-ZnO heterojunction.
S. Santra et al./Chemical Physics Letters 604 (2014) 97–100 99
leakage current 0.04 nA. Such p–n nano-heterojunctions may act as
basic building block for transparent electronics.
